1: <sup>1</sup> Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
2: <sup>2</sup> Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.
3: <sup>3</sup> A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.
4: <sup>4</sup> Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?
5: <sup>5</sup> Open rebuke is better than secret love.
6: <sup>6</sup> Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
7: <sup>7</sup> The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
8: <sup>8</sup> As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.
9: <sup>9</sup> Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.
10: <sup>10</sup> Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
11: <sup>11</sup> My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.
12: <sup>12</sup> A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.
13: <sup>13</sup> Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
14: <sup>14</sup> He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
15: <sup>15</sup> A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
16: <sup>16</sup> Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which bewrayeth itself.
17: <sup>17</sup> Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
18: <sup>18</sup> Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.
19: <sup>19</sup> As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.
20: <sup>20</sup> Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
21: <sup>21</sup> As the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.
22: <sup>22</sup> Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.
23: <sup>23</sup> Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.
24: <sup>24</sup> For riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?
25: <sup>25</sup> The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
26: <sup>26</sup> The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.
27: <sup>27</sup> And thou shalt have goats’ milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance for thy maidens.
